video.title: PyTorch for Deep Learning - Full Course / Tutorial
video.description:
In this course, you will learn how to build deep learning models with PyTorch and Python. The course makes PyTorch a bit more approachable for people starting out with deep learning and neural networks.

💻 Code:
https://jovian.ml/aakashns/01-pytorch-basics
https://jovian.ml/aakashns/02-linear-regression
https://jovian.ml/aakashns/03-logistic-regression
https://jovian.ml/aakashns/04-feedforward-nn
https://jovian.ml/aakashns/05-cifar10-cnn
https://jovian.ml/aakashns/05b-cifar10-resnet
https://jovian.ml/aakashns/06-mnist-gan

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:03:25) PyTorch Basics & Linear Regression
⌨️ (1:32:15) Image Classification with Logistic Regression
⌨️ (3:06:59) Training Deep Neural Networks on a GPU with PyTorch
⌨️ (4:44:51) Image Classification using Convolutional Neural Networks
⌨️ (6:35:11) Residual Networks, Data Augmentation and Regularization
⌨️ (8:12:08) Training Generative Adverserial Networks (GANs)

topLevelComment.author: Raj
topLevelComment.text:
What is the use of building intuition by trying out different hyper parameters, when we have Gaussian process optimization that can learn a function of hyperparameters and estimated loss and accuracy?

can you please explain the disadvantages of this method?

This way trial and error approach is replaced by a mathematical model ?

replies.author: Raj
replies.text:
@S. SANTHOSH 
The best way to learn to master mathematics behind  this subject ...believe me after this you will not have to remember  any thing ...everything  will just start flowing 

This best prerequisite  for this going to be  👇👇
https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PL1xHD4vteKYVpaIiy295pg6_SY5qznc77

It is highly  mathematical, with trying to visualize  the models in vector spaces ...so keep digressing  into math & statistics books  when ever you don't understand  anything

replies.author: S. SANTHOSH
replies.text: Tq bro 👍🏻

replies.author: Raj
replies.text:
don't learn data science  , learn machine learning models first algebraicly ...then interpret  it using matrices  ....then try to visualize those model in vector spaces ....

after this level of abstraction  this will feel like nothing .......it will just be matrix multiplication  and vectors transforming in column (vector)space of the input

topLevelComment.author: J S
topLevelComment.text:
I watched the MNIST section in linear modeling, and I also read the jupyter notebook from the link you provided. I don't think you applied softmax activation before the cross_entropy loss function. why is that ?
You took logits from nn.Linear(), then you did loss_fn(logits, labels).
I think you should do logits from nn.Linear(), then y_probs = F.softmax(logits, dim=1), then loss_fn(y_probs, labels). Am I correct ?

replies.author: Blazer913
replies.text: I think that in the previous webinar regarding logistic regression he stated that the cross_entropy function in PyTorch automatically applied softmax to the inputs, so you no longer need to do it beforehand.

topLevelComment.author: Alessandro Pepe

For instance, notebook 3 is now at version 32 which is substantially different from the video content and in order to get the matching version you've to revert the notebook back to version 6. Note this is not a complaint, just a constrictive suggestion of improvement. Thank you again for sharing this.

topLevelComment.text: Hi Akash, Thanks for the video. I am still watching. One doubt/clarification. at around 01:20:00, regarding SGD.   loss=loss_fn(model(inputs),target)
How can I fix this?

replies.author: Sillicon

topLevelComment.author: Mirror Neuron
topLevelComment.text: why w.grad.zero_() is done?

topLevelComment.author: Nithesh
topLevelComment.text:
Hi, 

Why we are doing only subtraction every time? 

What if the w.grad is negative? Don't we write like this w += w.grad * 1e-5 ?

with torch.no_grad():
    w -= w.grad * 1e-5
    b -= b.grad * 1e-5
    w.grad.zero_()
    b.grad.zero_()


Thanks in advance

replies.author: Nithesh
replies.text: @Rajat Varma Thank you

replies.author: Rajat Varma
replies.text: 1e-5 is the learning rate, we update the parameters (w and b)  using the equation w = w-dw*lr and b= b- db*lr.  dw cannot be negative as w and b is being passed through an activation function like sigmoid and relu. I hope that clears your doubt. remember w and b are not single numbers, they are vectors(matrices to be more specific).

replies.author: Quincy Larson
replies.text: @bronskie1974 Indian English is just as legitimate a speaking style as American English or Australian English. We are all former colonies of the British Empire, speaking our own variants of the language. Instead of feeling divided, we should feel united in our independence from Britain. Also, Indian English is easy to understand once you've spent some time listening to it. I encourage you to make some more Indian friends.
